items.title: "tweepy.error.TweepError: Could not determine file type" error when trying to upload jpg image.

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Issue regarding a bug with the library

items.body:
I'm trying to upload a image using this code:
```python
media = api.media_upload('quote.jpg', f)
api.update_status(status="foo", media_ids=[media.media_id_string])
```

**Expected Results**

Tweepy uploads the image with the message "foo".

**Actual Results**

Tweepy fails to upload the image because it can't guess the filetype using imghdr.what().

**Possible Solution**

Use mimetypes and/or magic as a fallback if imghdr fails.


**Traceback**

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "planetexpressbot.py", line 30, in <module>
    media = api.media_upload('quote.jpg', f)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tweepy/api.py", line 229, in media_upload
    headers, post_data = API._pack_image(filename, max_size,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/tweepy/api.py", line 1392, in _pack_image
    raise TweepError('Could not determine file type')
tweepy.error.TweepError: Could not determine file type
```

auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(api_key, api_secret)

items.title: Multiple streamlisteners possible?
items.body:
Hello! I was wondering if I could get some clarification on limits on the number of open streams you can have with a single account. 

What I've tried:

Made a simple streamlistener based on the tutorial here: http://docs.tweepy.org/en/latest/streaming_how_to.html. I then tried running 2 instances of that script simultaneously. It seems that I can run two scripts with no trouble but starting three or more leads to unpredictable behavior. Sometimes the new script runs, sometimes it shuts down with no exceptions raised. 

I've come across posts saying that you are only allowed to have one open stream at a time, and starting a new stream causes the old one to be killed. This is not the behavior I am seeing. Haven't been able to find anything in the official docs regarding this topic, would appreciate some clarification.

Thanks!

items.title: Streaming: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'filter' (similar to #1027)
items.body:
This seems similar to #1027, connected to #1026 and many previous issues, where the error was "'NoneType' object has no attribute 'strip'". I've been having this problem for some time, and my attempt to capture the exception also fail. This is with Tweepy v.3.8 running on Python 3.5. The current code unsuccessfully attempts to relaunch the stream, without a progressive delay for now; earlier versions didn't have the `start_stream` function or the try/except branch but I got the same error. Current code is more or less:

```
class MyStreamListener(tweepy.StreamListener):
   def on_data(self, data):
   # [etc.]

def run():
    # [stuff]
    auth = _get_auth(config)
    api = tweepy.API(auth)

    myListener = MyStreamListener(api)

    def start_stream(stream, **kwargs):
        try:
            stream.filter(**kwargs)
        except Exception:
            stream.disconnect()
            logger.error("Fatal exception")
            start_stream(stream, **kwargs) # TODO: add progressive backoff

    twitterStream = tweepy.Stream(auth=auth, listener=myListener)
    start_stream(twitterStream.sample(is_async=True))
```
After running for some random amount of time--could be hours, could be days--this eventually throws the error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "my-bot.py", line 208, in start_stream
    stream.filter(**kwargs)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'filter'
```
(line 208 is the `stream.filter(**kwargs)` line in the `try` statement)

I then get the parallel error from the `except` branch `"AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'disconnect'`.

Happy to supply any additional information. Would be grateful for a solution.

items.title: Premium search support?

labels.name: Duplicate
labels.description: Issue is a duplicate of another

items.body:
Hey, the tweepy function `api.search()` uses an endpoint at twitter which has an index of only 6-9 days (It's called "standard search"). Now, Twitter also has a "Premium search", which had to be enabled at https://developer.twitter.com/en/account/environments ...

Then in some "quick'n'dirty hack", I simply modified this tweepy code: https://github.com/tweepy/tweepy/blob/718e2de71ca545db3d3cd919fc96906ddde6f2a0/tweepy/api.py#L1274-L1281

to this:

    path='/tweets/search/fullarchive/dev.json',

which instead of the "Standard search" url

https://api.twitter.com/1.1/search/tweets.json

then creates the "Premium Search" url

https://api.twitter.com/1.1/tweets/search/fullarchive/dev.json

but then the twitter server answers with a 422

    tweepy.error.TweepError: Twitter error response: status code = 422

so I am doing something wrong here.

Please 

(a) help me how to get the "Premium search" going with some "quick'n'dirty hack", and   
(b) consider to later support it officially within tweepy. 

Thanks a lot! Great library, keep up the good work.

items.title: Including attachments in direct messages
items.body:
Thank you for creating Tweepy, it has been a huge time saver! It took me a bit to figure out the two-step process for uploading and sending an image attachment in a direct message. Part of this request is for an update to the docs, and part is a possible update to the Tweepy code base.

For the code base update, sending direct messages with attachments actually does require that all five arguments are included. Even if you don't want to use Quick Reply Type, you have to insert something (e.g. None) to get the rest of the code to work. Best case, it would be great to update Tweepy so that won't error out.

In the interim, you could include a code snippet that shows the process for uploading and then attaching a file to the direct message. Here is an example:

    img = api.media_upload('filepath')
    api.send_direct_message(recipient_id, 'text', None, 'media', img.media_id)

(you have to specify None for the quick reply field, and 'media' for image/gif/video content)

Hello,

I got an issue while trying to download tweets of a list thx to this code : 
`# Grap multiple user's user_timeline from twitter API and save to Excel
# Code will be save user's tweet ID, created Time, Coordinates-x, Coordinates-y, source, text. Can be modified at line 48 and so on
# Original code from https://gist.github.com/yanofsky/5436496  "A script to download all of a user's tweets into a csv"

import xlsxwriter

#https://github.com/tweepy/tweepy

consumer_key = "x"
consumer_secret = "x"
access_key = "x-x"
access_secret = "x"

def get_all_tweets(screen_name):

    auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
    auth.set_access_token(access_key, access_secret)
    api = tweepy.API(auth)

    alltweets = []
    new_tweets = []
    outtweets = []

    alltweets.extend(new_tweets)

	#save the id of the oldest tweet less one
    oldest = alltweets[-1].id - 1

    #keep grabbing tweets until there are no tweets left to grab
    while len(new_tweets) > 0:
        print ("getting tweets before %s" % oldest)

        #all subsiquent requests use the max_id param to prevent duplicates
        new_tweets = api.user_timeline(screen_name = screen_name,count=200,max_id=oldest)

        #save most recent tweets
        alltweets.extend(new_tweets)

        #update the id of the oldest tweet less one
        oldest = alltweets[-1].id - 1

        print ("...%s tweets downloaded so far" % len(alltweets))

    #transform the tweepy tweets into a 2D array
    outtweets = [[tweet.id_str, tweet.created_at, tweet.coordinates,tweet.geo,tweet.source,tweet.text] for tweet in alltweets]

    return outtweets

def write_worksheet(twitter_name):
